Title: THE SEAT OF WAR IN THE FAR WEST.
Abstract: The lines of JEFF. DAVIS' rebellion extend over a vast region of territory. The westernmost of his bloody outposts is among the far-distant, wild mountains of New-Mexico, on the upper waters of the Rio Grande. Of the fierce battle that was fought there on the 2lst ult., at the hamlet of Valyerde, we have already given the particulars.

Title: THE BATTLE OF VALVERDE.
Abstract: The following dispatch was received here tonight: KANSAS CITY, Tuesday, March 18. GEORGE T. BEALE, bearer of dispatches to Washington, brings advices from Sante Fe to the 3d inst. He confirms previous accounts of the battle near For Craig on the 21st ult. The Federal loss was 62 killed and 546 wounded. The Texans captured six of our field pieces. Col. STEELE commanded the Texans. The Texans were at Soccres, 38 miles north of Fort Craig. Col. CANDY'S command was con..

Title: THE BATTLE IN NEW-MEXICO.
Abstract: The St. Louis Republican has advices from Albuqurque, New-Mexico, of Feb. 23, which state that the Texans have made various significant movements in the vicinity of Fort Craig. On the 18th they advanced a column of infantry, a thousand strong, in line of battle, in front of the Fort, and also moved a column of 800 cavalry to the West of our defenses. They advance to within a mile and a-half of the works, with the rebel flag floating in the breeze. They

Title: IMPORTANT FROM NEW-MEXICO
Abstract: The following news was received, here, to-day by military express: A desperate and terrible battle, lasting all day, took place at Valverde, ten miles south of Fort Craig, on the 2lst of February.
